cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 119 (Wednesday, July 12, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mrs. HINSON:H.R. 4581.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1, Section 8 of the Constitution of the UnitedStatesThe single subject of this legislation is:This bill expands the scope of the Maternal and ChildHealth Services Block Grant to include research andactivities to prevent stillbirths.[Page H3477]

item.title: Maternal and Child Health Stillbirth Prevention Act

item.text: Became Public Law No: 118-69.
Became Public Law No: 118-69.
Signed by President.
Signed by President.
Presented to President.
Presented to President.
Message on Senate action sent to the House.
Passed Senate without amendment by Unanimous Consent. (consideration: CR S4023)
Passed/agreed to in Senate: Passed Senate without amendment by Unanimous Consent. (consideration: CR S4023)
Received in the Senate, read twice.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 408 - 3 (Roll no. 207). (text: 5/14/2024 CR H3028)
Passed/agreed to in House: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 408 - 3 (Roll no. 207). (text: 5/14/2024 CR H3028)
Considered as unfinished business. (consideration: CR H3254-3255)

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4581.
Considered under suspension of the rules. (consideration: CR H3028-3029)
Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended.
Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 406.
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Energy and Commerce. H. Rept. 118-490.
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Energy and Commerce. H. Rept. 118-490.
Ordered to be Reported (Amended) by the Yeas and Nays: 44 - 0.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held
Forwarded by Subcommittee to Full Committee (Amended) by the Yeas and Nays: 25 - 0.
Subcommittee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held
Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.
Introduced in House

cdata.text:
Maternal and Child Health Stillbirth Prevention Act of 2023

This bill expands the scope of the Maternal and Child Health Services Block Grant to include research and activities to prevent stillbirths.

Maternal and Child Health Stillbirth Prevention Act of 2024

This bill expands the scope of the Maternal and Child Health Services Block Grant to include research and activities to prevent stillbirths.

Maternal and Child Health Stillbirth Prevention Act of 2024

This bill expands the scope of the Maternal and Child Health Services Block Grant to include research and activities to prevent stillbirths.

Maternal and Child Health Stillbirth Prevention Act of 2024

This bill expands the scope of the Maternal and Child Health Services Block Grant to include research and activities to prevent stillbirths.

Maternal and Child Health Stillbirth Prevention Act of 2024

This act expands the scope of the Maternal and Child Health Services Block Grant to include research and activities to prevent stillbirths.

item.title: Maternal and Child Health Stillbirth Prevention Act of 2024
Maternal and Child Health Stillbirth Prevention Act of 2024
To amend title V of the Social Security Act to support stillbirth prevention and research, and for other purposes.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
